p: Theoretical and empirical studies have demonstrated that migration evolves to maximize fitness in a seasonal environment [ 1, 2]. Migratory animals thereby target the most profitable areas [ 3], balancing their energy requirements with available resources, within ever-changing ecological landscapes. Such complex spatio-temporal match/mismatch of migratory species with their biotic and abiotic environments shape migratory dynamics and the fate of populations on the move [ 3, 4]. Migrating animals are thus particularly vulnerable to climate change and resulting environmental modifications [ 3, 5, 6]. Among birds, most long-distance migrants breed at high latitudes, where climatic changes have the strongest amplitude and seasonally travel to more favourable wintering grounds [ 7, 8]. Overall, this puts a strong emphasis on the migratory ecology of birds in a warming Arctic [ 9].
